title: If my story is set in 30 years from now, can I write it in past tense first person? Will it make sense? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sure. Many futuristic novels are written in the past tense. You just have to have a clear vision of what happens between the ending of your story and your narrator’s present, so that this can inform how he or she looks back on things. An excellent example of this, albeit not set in the future, is John Maddox Roberts’ SPQR series, which is set in the waning days of the Roman Republic. The narrator and main protagonist is a fictitious Roman Senator named Decius Caecillius Metellus. He’s “writing” about the events of the 70s to the 40s BCE, but he’s doing so decades later, during the reign of Augustus (whom he despises). He is continually comparing the Rome of “then” (when the story is happening) and “now” (when he’s old and bitter and the Republic is dead and every has to kiss one ruler’s ass).

I suppose so, but you must be absolutely careful to hold true to the new reality and the new past of the intervening 30 years, which in my view will be harder than extracting a rattlesnake’s molars without anesthetic.
